bioghist.p: William H. Helfand is a consultant to the National Library of Medicine, the Philadelphia Museum of Art and other institutions in areas relating to art and medicine, and a member of the Board of Trustees of the Library Company of Philadelphia. He has degrees in Chemical Engineering (University of Pennsylvania, 1948), Pharmacy (Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science, 1952). Before his retirement in 1987, he had worked for more than 33 years as an executive with Merck and Co., the multinational pharmaceutical company. He is a noted collector of ephemera, much of it related to medicine and pharmaceuticals. Exhibitions of portions of his collection have been held at the Philadelphia Museum of Art and the National Library of Medicine, among other institutions. Helfand is the author of several books and a number of articles on the history of pharmacy and medicine and on printed ephemera related to these fields.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of 19th century comic valentines, which lampoon men and women for aspects of their work and gender roles. Most of them are American, but there are a few from England as well. Several have an extra sheet of blank paper for writing a message. Several have no verses.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
